awd_titl_txt: Automated, Secure Homotopy Continuation and Parameter Space Exploration
awd_abstract_narration:
Systems of polynomial equations arise naturally in most scientific and engineering fields.  These systems describe the motion of robotic arms, the steady states of biochemical reactions, the location of radio transmitters based on sensor readings, and many other science and engineering scenarios that are rooted in physical laws and geometry.  The solution of polynomial systems was nearly impossible until roughly fifty years ago, and efficient methods are still being developed and analyzed.  The first broad direction of this project seeks to automate the tuning of some of these methods (so that non-experts can use them readily) and to incorporate more certainty in the computations.  The second broad direction seeks to further develop methods that are particularly useful in applications and to make progress on a few particular applications, namely, biochemical reaction networks, geolocation, and population genetics.  Three graduate students will be involved in the project.

Homotopy continuation is a fundamental computational tool of numerical algebraic geometry, on which virtually all advanced algorithms within the field depend.  While there has been much theoretical and algorithmic development on this topic over the years, there are still at least three basic problems to be addressed.  First, ill-conditioning forces the use of expensive high-precision numerical computations and sometimes path failure.  Second, homotopy continuation depends on a number of numerical tolerances that are highly problem-dependent and difficult to adjust, especially for non-experts.  Third, numerical methods are inherently inexact, making them undesirable in some contexts.  The three projects of the first research direction seek to make progress on solving these problems.  Fundamental scientific and engineering questions frequently involve parameters, and their solution depends on the ability to understand and move around parameter spaces effectively.  The three projects of the second direction aim to further develop numerical homotopy methods for parameter space exploration.  The first project will advance our ability to collect useful data from Euclidean parameter spaces, particularly when the goal is to find points in parameter space at which a parameterized polynomial system has a special kind of solution set.  The second project aims to extend homotopy continuation to general algebraic parameter spaces.  The third project is an assortment of applications, as mentioned.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported several projects related to the numerical solution of polynomial systems.  These projects included applications in the areas of biochemical reaction networks and RF emitter geolocation, improvements to fundamental methods within the field of numerical algebraic geometry, and algorithmic and software contributions. This award also provided partial support for the co-PI’s efforts in supervising two PhD students and two undergraduates, the co-organization of several scientific meetings, dissemination to a broad audience via publications and presentations, and the development of a book aimed at introducing the area to new users. 

A fundamental question with chemical reaction networks is whether different outcomes can be achieved with mild changes to the input. One way to approach this problem is through experimentation in a chemistry lab.  A more cost-effective approach is to coast the network as a polynomial system, with different types of mathematical solutions corresponding to different chemical outcomes. The co-PI worked with a former postdoc and a team from Harvard Medical School to investigate this connection between mathematics and chemistry on a particular biochemical reaction network. The result was an analysis of the so-called parameter geography of this problem, laying the foundation for others who might want to use such a computational approach to biochemical reaction networks. This work was the core of a Harvard Med PhD student’s thesis. In related work, the co-PI also worked with coauthors to produce a novel numerical approach to studying model identifiability.  

The fundamental computational engine in the parameter geography project is called a parameter homotopy.  The former postdoc, the co-PI, and another former PhD student recognized the value of developing specialized software aimed at expediting this particular computation and created Paramotopy.  An article about this software package and the underlying heuristics was published during the award period. 

Another project focused on the RF emitter geolocation problem.  With passive radar, radio frequency (RF) emitters send signals that are then detected by receivers. With enough measurements from enough receivers, the emitter can be located by solving a polynomial system. The co-PI worked on various versions of this problem with a PhD student and other coauthors. One result was a technique for assessing the quality of measurement data so as to solve the RF emitter geolocation problem with only the best available data. This result and a foundation for denoising noisy measurements were used by the PhD student as the core of her PhD thesis. This foundation for a denoising method was later developed into a heuristic by an undergraduate student in her senior honors thesis.

Other results were focused more on the discipline of numerical algebraic geometry, rather than specfic applicaitons. The central data type in numerical algebraic geometry is called the numerical irreducible decomposition. Most approaches to computing the numerical irreducible decomposition require several rounds of calculations. In the most commony used approaches, the number of rounds of calculations is close to the number of variables in the problem. With a few coauthors, the co-PI developed a technique to carry out most of this computation with just a single round of calculations. The co-PI and other coauthors also developed a very technical method that is particularly useful when trying to find the real solutions of a polynomial system, which are typically buried within complex solution sets.

The broader impacts of this award include the direct supervision of two PhD students (one completed, one ongoing) and two senior honors theses (both completed), along with indirect mentorship of several other graduate students, postdocs, and early career mathematicians. The co-PI has also been working with a group of coauthors on a book aimed at introducing the discipline to new users, particularly advanced undergraduate students seeking independent study projects. The co-PI continues to stay active in his research community, with this award partially supporting the co-organization of six professional meetings of various sorts and a semester-long program at a research institute, seven professional presentations by the co-PI (three at international-level conferences), and several other presentations given by students.
